data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Dark User Interface, Dark Behaviour? The Effect of 'Dark Mode' on Honesty

other.value:
An additional (second) hypothesis is that perceived anonymity mediates the relationship of UI to honesty (i.e., a dark UI leads to greater perceived anonymity and therefore to greater dishonesty). This will be explored with three regressions (UI on honesty, perceived anonymity on honesty, and UI & perceived anonymity on honesty) and tested with a Sobel test for mediation (using PROCESS for SPSS, inputting honesty as outcome variable Y, UI as independent variable X, and perceived anonymity as mediator variable M).

A final (third) hypothesis is that the effect of UI on honesty, as well as the effect of perceived anonymity on honesty, will depend on financial well-being (i.e., the honesty of those low in financial well-being is less affected by [or entirely insensitive to] UI/perceived anonymity). Interaction effects are therefore expected (UI*financial well-being on honesty and perceived anonymity*financial well-being on honesty). This will be tested by adding financial well-being as a covariate to the above mentioned regressions (viz., UI on honesty and perceived anonymity on honesty). 

The following variables are collected for additional exploratory analyses:

- Age
- Sex
- Country of origin
- Lighting in participants' rooms ('dark' or 'light' [self-reported])
- Solar position derived from IP address (excluding participants that report the use of IP-altering software [e.g., a VPN, Tor browser, etc.]). Computing as min. 0% = before sunrise/after sunset, and max. 100% is at solar noon. PySolar will be used for this.
- Hours since waking up (whole number [self-reported])
- Preference for dark or light UI ('dark' or 'light' [self-reported])

It may further be good to state that this is a 'true' economic experiment. There is no deception involved and participants will be rewarded with actual money for their choices. All participants earn 0.3 $ for participation and can earn up to a bonus of 0.5 $ in the die roll game. All money is paid via MTurk. 

--- REFERENCES ---

Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis for the social sciences. Routledge.

CPFB. (2015). Measuring financial well-being: A guide to using the CPFB Financial Well-Being Scale. Retrieved from https://www.consumerfinance.gov/data research/research-reports/financial-well-being-scale/

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A. G., & Buchner, A. (2007). G* Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior research methods, 39(2), 175-191.

Fischbacher, U., & Föllmi-Heusi, F. (2013). Lies in disguise—an experimental study on cheating. Journal of the European Economic Association, 11(3), 525-547.

Hite, D. M., Voelker, T., & Robertson, A. (2014). Measuring perceived anonymity: The development of a context independent instrument. Journal of Methods and Measurement in the Social Sciences, 5(1), 22-39.

Rahwan, Z., Hauser, O. P., Kochanowska, E., & Fasolo, B. (2018). High stakes: A little more cheating, a lot less charity. Journal of Economic Behavior & Organization, 152, 276-295.

sample.value: 800 participants. Due to budget constraints, it is not possible to recruit in excess of this. However, this sample size provides good power. A sensitivity power analysis for the main hypothesis test (conducted with GPower 3.1 [Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007]), using a two-tailed alpha significance criterion of .05, a power criterion of .8, and two groups of 400 participants in an independent means t-test, showed a required effect size of .2 (Cohen’s d), which Cohen (1988) regards as ‘small’.

analyses.value: The main hypothesis (dark UI users are more dishonest than light UI users) is tested with a two-tailed t-test, comparing honesty between the two conditions.

outliers.value:
The die roll game, perceived anonymity scale, and financial well-being scale have limited options. No (problematic) outliers can occur. No participants will be excluded on base of these variables.

To protect data quality, considering that participants are recruited via Amazon MTurk, the following measures are taken:

- >= 90% approval rate (MTurk criteria)
- >= 50 HITs completed (MTurk criteria)
- Located in the US (MTurk criteria)
- Passing of CAPTCHA required (cannot continue otherwise)
- Passing of four attention checks required (survey is terminated otherwise)
- A unique IP address is required (in case of multiple entries from 1 IP address, all related entires are excluded)
- The main survey and die roll game survey may only be opened once per participant (to be checked using IP address and MTurk ID [asked at the start of both surveys]. If a survey has been opened more than once past the point of entering the MTurk ID, all related entries will be excluded)
- Full completion of both the main and die roll game survey (all incomplete entries will be excluded)

dependent.value:
'Honesty'. Measured in an online die roll game (based off Rahwan, Hauser, Kochnawoska, and Fasolo [2018] and Fischbacher and Föllmi-Heusi [2013]). Participants play ten rounds. They are instructed to roll a fair, six-sided die in each round and report the outcome. If they report 1 to 5, they will earn the reported number in $ cent. If they report 6, they earn nothing. The total bonus earned over the ten rounds forms this variable.

'Perceived anonymity'. Measured using a scale of Hite, Voelker, and Robertson (2014). The scale is set up to measure anonymity as experienced by participants during the die roll game.

'Financial well-being'. Measured using the scale of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (2015).

conditions.value: Two conditions: a 'dark' (1) and a 'light' (2) UI for the duration of the die roll game.

hypothesis.value: Are users of a 'dark' user interface (UI) more dishonest than users of a 'light' UI?

attributes.title: Support to asylum seeker policies
attributes.description: The project investigated the relationships between ideologically conservative attitudes (social dominance orientation, SDO; right-wing authoritarianism, RWA), legitimizing myths (false belief in asylum seekers as bogus; perception of in-group threats), and citizens’ support for restricted reception and rejection of asylum policies in a sample of 539 people living in Italy.

attributes.title: Risk Factors for Rapid Chondrolysis After Partial Lateral Meniscectomy: A Scoping Review of the Literature
attributes.description:
Rapid chondrolysis following partial lateral meniscectomy is rare. The risk factors and pathophysiology of this complication have not been established.

The purpose was to perform a scoping review of the literature in order to determine potential risk factors and pathogenesis.

summary.value:
This is a registration of study before collecting data according to the method described below.

Methods: A search strategy based on the terms [“Chondrolysis” AND “Knee”],  [“Chondrolysis” AND “Meniscus”] and [“Chondral damage” AND “ Lateral meniscus”]  was applied to the PubMed database on 23th March 2020. All relevant studies were included. Patient demographics and clinical data were extracted from these studies and analyzed in order to provide an overview of the characteristics of patients who were diagnosed with rapid chondrolysis.

attributes.title: Psychological Distance in Persuasion
attributes.description: This research examines a new model to simplify explanations of social influence (e.g., persuasion): The 3D(istances) of Persuasion. We postulate that perceptions of psychological distance have to be considered as the basis which underlies the evaluation of e.g., the credibility of a source or veracity of a message. The model differentiates three psychological distances, one for each combination of two of recipient, communicator, and attitude object. The planned research starts with testing one distance. We assume that a relatively short (vs. long) subjectively perceived distance between communicator and attitude object increases the persuasive power of a given message. This hypothesis will be tested in three studies.

q1.value: Scarlett Friedrich, Roman Linne, Hans-Peter Erb

q2.value:
H1: Messages from sources relatively close (vs. more distant) to the attitude object have a greater impact on participants´ attitudes.

H1.1: In Studies 1 and 3, attitude objects will be evaluated more positively if the source arguing in favor of the attitude object is spatially close to it, and the source arguing against the attitude object is more distant to it. Vice versa, if the source arguing against the attitude object is spatially close and the source arguing in favor of it is distant, we expect a more negative attitude.

H1.2: In Study 2, we expect participants to evaluate a given story (about an incident) as more plausible if the source of the story is spatially close (vs. distant) to the place where the incident occurred. 


H2: Source credibility mediates the influence of distance on attitude change. 


H3: Although not the focus of the present research, similarity of communicator and recipient characteristics will increase persuasion due to closeness. We use gender as a proximal variable of closeness and predict that same gender communicators are more influential than different gender communicators.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Data collection is online, therefore no researchers are involved in data collection.

question.value: The experiment follows a 2 x 4 mixed-method design with psychological distance (positive close / negative distant vs. negative close / positive distant) as a between-subject factor and gender (female close positive, male close positive, female close negative, male close negative) as a within-subject factor. We counterbalance the communicators' gender such that an equal amount of female and male sources present a close and distant commentary of both valences. It should be noted that every participant takes part in each of the three named studies.

q7.value: Participants will be allocated to the between subjects conditions by a randomization procedure provided by the online tool.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: We have started with data collection prior to preregistration (not completed as of yet). Additionally, we have already seen a small portion of data. However, no analyses with regard to the research plan have been conducted.

question.value: Participants are recruited through informational emails and through postings in social media. Students of our university can receive credits for their participation. Beyond that we offer no other form of compensation. Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to understand the questionnaire in order to take part.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 102 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 120, assuming that not all will fully complete the experimental task.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .50 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
In Studies 1 and 3, we manipulate the distance between source and attitude object as well as the valence of the presented messages. We present participants in both conditions with descriptions from two sources: Either a positive message from a close source and a negative message from a distant source (Condition 1) or a negative message from a close source and a positive message from a distant source (Condition 2). 
In Study 2, the IV is the distance between the alleged location of a source of a story about a given incident and the place the incident allegedly took place.

Our dependent variables are attitudes (Studies 1 and 3) and the likelihood of occurrence (Study 2). In Studies 1 and 3, we assess participants’ attitudes via two items, which will be averaged for data analyses. First, we ask “How do you think about [name of city/recreational activity provider]?” on a 7-point scale, ranging from 1 = “very negative” to 7 = “very positive”. Secondly, “Could you imagine to visit [name of city/recreational activity provider]?”, on a 7-point scale, ranging from 1 = “by no means” to 7 = “absolutely”. Also in Studies 1 and 3 we let the participants decide which source they perceived to be more credible: “Which source do you think is more credible?”. Participants express their opinion via slider with the names of both sources as the endpoints. In Study 2, we assess the perceived credibility via a slightly different single item:  “How credible do you think [name of the source] is?”, rated on a 7-point scale with 1 = “not at all credible“ and 7 = “very credible”. 

In Study 2, we ask participants to evaluate the probability of occurrence of each described event with a single item: “How likely do you think is it that the event occurred as described?”, ranging from 1 = “highly unlikely” to 7 = “very likely”.  

For exploratory reasons, we ask participants in Study 2 to additionally rate the source's expertise “Would you ascribe [name of source] expert knowledge?” on 7-point scale ranging from 1 = “not at all” till 7 = “absolutely”.

H1: The first hypothesis will be analyzed with a series of independent t-tests. We will compute t-tests for Studies 1 (attitude toward city/town; close positive and distant negative vs. close negative and distant positive), 2 (likelihood of incident; close source vs. distant source), and 3 (attitude toward recreational activity provider; close positive and distant negative vs. close negative and distant positive). Furthermore, we will compute two mixed-method ANOVAs across Study1 and Study 2. The first ANOVA tests for attitude evaluation with distance as between-subjects factor and a stimulus replication (averaged evaluations in Study 1 vs. averaged evaluations in Study 3) as within-subject factor, testing whether assumed effects are valid for different operationalizations. The second ANOVA tests for attitude evaluation / incident likelihood with distance as between-subject factor and the evaluations of Studies 1 and 3 as well as likelihood estimations of Study 2 as dependent variables. A priori contrasts will be used to test for differences between Studies 1 and 3 on the one hand and Study 2 on the other hand (thus,  possible differences between object evaluations and likelihood estimations as a function of psychological distance). 

H2: The mediation hypothesis will be tested using mediated regression analysis (using PROCESS, Hayes, 2018). Distance will be included as the predictor, source credibility as a mediator and attitude object evaluations (Studies 1 and 3) / likelihood of occurrence (Study 2) as outcomes.

H3: For Hypothesis 3, we will first compute a new variable define the gender-matching of participant and source / source valence (for Studies 1 and 3: fit-positive, fit-negative; for Study 2: fit, no fit) for each presented stimulus. Subsequently, mixed-method ANOVAs will be computed. First, per study, we compute a mixed-method ANOVA for attitude object evaluation (1 and 3) or likelihood of occurrence (2) with distance as a between-subject factor and gender-matching (Studies 1 and 3: positive-fit vs. negative-fit; Study 2: yes vs. no) as a within-subject factor. Second, similar to the description of H1, stimulus replication (Study 1 vs. Study 3) / DV (attitude object evaluation, likelihood of occurrence; Studies 1 and 3 vs. Study 2) will be added as further within-subject factors. 

As manipulation check (MC) we present participants with three stimuli, each a repetition from the studies participants have completed prior to MC. For each stimulus participants are asked to evaluate the distance between the source(s) and the respective attitude object as well as how familiar participants think the source(s) is/are with the respective attitude object. 
Participants rating sources allegedly closer to the attitude object as spatially close and as more familiar with it compared to sources located more distant to the attitude object indicates a successful manipulation.

q20.value: We will exclude participants who have guessed the purpose of the study correctly.

attributes.title: MeMO: Me and My Objects
attributes.description: This project examines the relationships between people and their objects. In particular, we are interested in the cognitive behavioural features of the acquisition and saving of objects, particularly in relation to people who experience hoarding tendencies, to understand how these emerge and are maintained over time. We are currently conducting and planning several studies exploring the role of memory in hoarding, and, how the memories that people associate with some objects can make people want to own more of these objects and also how it can make these objects difficult to discard once they have been acquired.

copyright_holders: Sarah Densham; Dr James Gregory; Prof Tom Barry; Kristy Lam

q2.value: Tom Barry, James Gregory, Sarah Densham, Kristy Lam

q3.value:
Previous research has demonstrated associations between experiences of trauma and the presence of an over general memory (OGM) bias for autobiographical memories. A history of traumatic experiences is more commonly found in those with Hoarding Disorder (HD) compared to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) groups, and it has been suggested that HD may be developed in response to traumatic events. HD may act as a habitual buffer to prevent hyper-arousal or re-experiencing of symptoms associated with traumatic events.  This shares similarities with the CaRFAX model, wherein individuals maintain an overgeneral memory (OGM) as a means of functional avoidance. 
The presence of an OGM bias has not been investigated in HD.  This is important as OGM has been found to contribute to the aetiology and the maintenance of various mental health difficulties (Williams, et al., 2007), with new psychological treatments being developed to target OGM (Hitchcock, Werner-Seidler, Blackwell, & Dalgleish, 2017).

This study aims to increase understanding of HD by:
- investigating whether there is a presence of an OGM bias in HD, compared with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) and community control (CC) groups
- Exploring whether severity of HD (low, medium, high) is associated with an OGM bias.
-investigating whether trauma is associated with OGM bias, and whether this is differs as a function of group
- Exploring whether prevalence of trauma is associated with OGM bias in HD.
- Exploring whether trauma-related factors (e.g. trauma type) are associated with OGM bias in HD.

This study will also aim to provide exploratory descriptive data related to:
-the presence of objects in reported memories, and whether this differs as a function of group
-the presence of object-related acquisition, discard, emotional attachment, decision making in memories and whether this differs as a function of group

q4.value:
There will be a difference in overgeneral memory (OGM) bias between Hoarding Disorder (HD), OCD and community control (CC) groups.

Irrespective of group, individuals with a reported history of trauma would show a greater OGM bias than would those with no reported trauma history.

The HD group will report a greater trauma history in comparison to OCD and CC groups.

Individuals with more severe HD in the HD group will show a greater OGM bias.

OGM bias will be moderated by trauma (e.g. frequency and type) in the HD group.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through connections from the University of Bath (e.g. those involved in prior HD research), the university department's participant pool, local HD organisations, social media and community locations. 

Participants must be over 18 years old. For participants in the HD/OCD groups, they must meet the criteria for HD/OCD and present with HD/OCD as their primary problem. Those in the community control (CC) group must have no current diagnosis of a mental health problem. 

Participants will be excluded if they have are currently receiving psychological treatment, have an insufficient command of the English language, a neurological disorder, previous experience of ECT or are dependent on substances.

There will be two phases in this study, both of which take place online. Screening measures and questionnaires will be completed online.

Data will be collected from October 2019 until October 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 90 participants, with approximately 30 participants in each group (HD, OCD, CC).

question.value:
Predictor variables are hoarding severity and trauma-related variables. Hoarding severity will be measured by the Saving Inventory - Revised (SI-R; Frost, Steketee & Grisham, 2004). Trauma-related variables will be measured using the Life Experience Checklist (LEC; Gray, Litz, Hsu & Lombardo, 2004). 

The outcome variable is autobiographical memory specificity, which will be operationalised as the number of specific memories recalled in response to cue words. This will be tested using the Autobiographical Memory Test (AMT).

Group descriptives regarding depression, anxiety, age, gender, IQ, education level  will be reported. One way anova will be conducted to investigate any group differences in these variables.

A two way mixed factorial ANOVA will be conducted to explore whether there is a main effect of group, main effect of cue and any interaction between group*cue on the dependent variable specificity. The independent variables are the participant group (HD/OCD/CC) and cue valence the dependent variable is memory specificity. 

These analyses will be run with and without relevant covariates, as identified through early analysis of group differences in the following variables: depression, anxiety, IQ, age, education, gender. 

Descriptive data for each group (HD, CC, OCD) regarding trauma exposure will be provided as a dichotomous variable (indicating the presence of at least one endorsed lifetime trauma ) and as a composite score.

One way anova may be used to explore whether there are group differences in trauma exposure. with post hoc tests to analyse the quality of differences.

We may use an ANCOVA to investigate whether there is a main effect of trauma (as a dichotomous or composite score) or an interaction between group* trauma on the DV specificity. Furthermore, we may investigate whether trauma exposure predicts specificity and whether this differs as a function of group, a linear regression will be used to test the predictive ability of the interaction between group*trauma on the DV specificity. 

Participants who complete the study screening variables but are ineligible to participate in the main study variables will be excluded from any further analysis. Any responses considered to be fraudulent in nature (e.g. duplicates) will be removed from the dataset. Analyses will be conducted with and without the presence of outliers, and any influence of outliers on the results will be reported. 

Missing data
 
Where there are omissions or missing data in participant responses on the AMT task, missing responses will not be imputed and participants will not be excluded on this basis. This is because omissions/missing data are informative for understanding memory ability if a memory is not reported. Omissions/missing data will be calculated alongside the raw number of specific memories so that this information is explicit and transparent. There are no formal guidelines for dealing with missing data on the LEC. Any missing data on this variable will be noted and will not be imputed.

Exploratory analysis
 
As, to our knowledge, no investigation of this nature has yet been conducted, we will operationalise the presence of objects in memories as the % and raw number of memories where objects are reported (by group), because this provides a descriptive understanding of object representation across memories, irrespective of the number of objects described within each memory. Further exploration may entail investigating whether the % of memories where objects are present differs as a function of group using a one way ANOVA. Similarly, the meaning of objects in the memories where objects are present will be operationalised by coding descriptions of object-related acquisition, discard, emotional attachment, decision making. The % of memories where object-related acquisition, discard, emotional attachment and decision making are present will be provided (by group). Further exploration will investigate group differences in object-related meaning using ANOVA. Further exploratory analyses may be conducted to reveal the % of specific and general memories, separately, where objects are present, and the % of specific and general memories, separately, where object-related acquisition, discard, emotional attachment and decision making are present (by group).

registration_responses.q2: Tom Barry, James Gregory, Sarah Densham, Kristy Lam
registration_responses.q3:
Previous research has demonstrated associations between experiences of trauma and the presence of an over general memory (OGM) bias for autobiographical memories. A history of traumatic experiences is more commonly found in those with Hoarding Disorder (HD) compared to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) groups, and it has been suggested that HD may be developed in response to traumatic events. HD may act as a habitual buffer to prevent hyper-arousal or re-experiencing of symptoms associated with traumatic events.  This shares similarities with the CaRFAX model, wherein individuals maintain an overgeneral memory (OGM) as a means of functional avoidance. 
The presence of an OGM bias has not been investigated in HD.  This is important as OGM has been found to contribute to the aetiology and the maintenance of various mental health difficulties (Williams, et al., 2007), with new psychological treatments being developed to target OGM (Hitchcock, Werner-Seidler, Blackwell, & Dalgleish, 2017).

This study aims to increase understanding of HD by:
- investigating whether there is a presence of an OGM bias in HD, compared with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) and community control (CC) groups
- Exploring whether severity of HD (low, medium, high) is associated with an OGM bias.
-investigating whether trauma is associated with OGM bias, and whether this is differs as a function of group
- Exploring whether prevalence of trauma is associated with OGM bias in HD.
- Exploring whether trauma-related factors (e.g. trauma type) are associated with OGM bias in HD.

This study will also aim to provide exploratory descriptive data related to:
-the presence of objects in reported memories, and whether this differs as a function of group
-the presence of object-related acquisition, discard, emotional attachment, decision making in memories and whether this differs as a function of group
registration_responses.q4:
There will be a difference in overgeneral memory (OGM) bias between Hoarding Disorder (HD), OCD and community control (CC) groups.

Irrespective of group, individuals with a reported history of trauma would show a greater OGM bias than would those with no reported trauma history.

The HD group will report a greater trauma history in comparison to OCD and CC groups.

Individuals with more severe HD in the HD group will show a greater OGM bias.

OGM bias will be moderated by trauma (e.g. frequency and type) in the HD group.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Friendship Jealousy Model - Jealousy Manipulation Study

other.value:
Whereas we predict that people in the friendship jealousy condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding (vigilance) than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition, we also explore--but do not explicitly predict--that people in the control condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in everyday friend retention behavior than friend guarding - vigilance. 

We explore the secondary prediction that currently-felt friendship jealousy ("jealousy" in the manipulation check) statistically mediates the relationship between condition and reported intent to engage in friend guarding - vigilance (whereas neutrality, happiness, sadness, and anger do not). 

*Above, we marked "It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless." We have begun data collection online; however, we have not analyzed these data.

sample.value: A priori power analysis indicated that approximately 350 participants would be required for .80 power to detect small- to medium-sized effects (f = .15) in friend guarding - vigilance between the two conditions, thus assessing our focal prediction.

analyses.value:
A 2 (condition) x 2 [friendship maintenance behavior] mixed-factors ANOVA with follow-up comparisons specifically aiming to explore the prediction that there is greater reported intent to engage in friend guarding - vigilance among Ps in the friendship jealousy versus the relatively neutral friend-related control condition.

We will then run a mediation analysis (PROCESS Model 4) to explore the secondary prediction that currently-felt friendship jealousy ("jealousy" in the manipulation check) statistically mediates the relationship between condition and reported intent to engage in friend guarding - vigilance (whereas neutrality, happiness, sadness, and anger do not).

outliers.value:
We have several bot and attention checks built into the survey. Participants' data will be excluded from analyses for failing any of the below. 

First, Ps must write the names of a same-sex best friend and a same-sex acquaintance (e.g., John), and are told not to use only initials. Those Ps skipping this question or failing it (e.g., by using John and Mary, two names that are highly unlikely to both be same-sex) will be excluded.

Second, Ps must respond to manipulations by writing. Ps whose replies are obviously not cogent (e.g., they are pasting text from previous questions, failing to connect to the prompt) will be excluded. 

Third, we also included an attention check item toward the end of the survey. (Asking Ps to write "ethnicity" in the text box below, with radio button choices being Sex/Gender, Ethnicity, Sexual orientation, and Age, with the Age choice including the text box for Ps to write in "ethnicity". Case matching was not required to pass this check. Those failing this attention check will be excluded. 

Fourth, we also have a manipulation check question directly following the manipulation. Related, Ps' replies to the manipulation also serve as a similar check. (a) We will analyze the data without excluding Ps based on these checks, first, as doing so simply adds noise to the data. (In our manipulation checks, we expect people in the friendship jealousy condition to feel greater friendship jealousy ["jealousy" in the survey] than those in the control condition. We expect people the in the control condition to feel a greater amount of aggregated neutrality and happiness than those in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition. Those in the friendship jealousy condition may also feel high levels of anger and/or sadness, emotions often concomitant with jealousy.)
Additionally, (b) an RA blind to hypotheses and conditions will read all non-excluded responses to the manipulations and rate each on the degree of jealously, neutrality (lack of strong emotions), happiness, anger, sadness expressed in each response on a 7-point scale (1= not at all, 7 = very much). People reporting jealousy below 4 in the friendship jealousy condition and people reporting a 4 or above on negative emotionality (anger, sadness, jealousy) in the control condition will be excluded in ancillary analysis b1, and those whose RA-scored responses are below 4 on jealousy in the friendship jealousy condition or 4 or above on negative emotionality (anger, sadness, jealousy) in the control condition will be excluded in ancillary analysis b2.

dependent.value:
As in Study 2, behavioral intent to engage in friend guarding- vigilance will be measured via two items (e.g., "Try to figure out if [best friend] prefers a new friend's company to your company") on a 7-point Likert-type scale. 

On the same scale, we also measure behavioral intent to engage in everyday friend retention behavior, as in Study 2.

conditions.value: Two conditions: Friendship jealousy, relatively neutral friend-related control.

hypothesis.value:
Do people who are currently experiencing friendship jealousy report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding (i.e., friend guarding- vigilance) than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition (who may be feeling relatively more neutral and/or happiness; i.e., not strong negative emotions). 

Whereas we predict that people in the friendship jealousy condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition, we also explore--but do not explicitly predict--whether people in the control condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in everyday friend retention behavior than friend guarding behavior.

attributes.title: Study 1: Social judgments of different occupations in the time of COVID-19
attributes.description: As explained, some occupations are essential to the functioning of the nation. For these occupations, workers continue to attend their workplace and are highly exposed to the virus. The aim of this first study is thus to analyze the social judgments made towards these occupations in the time of COVID-19. The results will make it possible to select occupations for which judgements differs in order to manipulate them in Study 2.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Study 1: Social judgments of different occupations in the time of COVID-19
The aim of this first study is thus to analyze the social judgments made towards these occupations in the time of covid-19.

other.value:
If there is some significant differences in social judgment towards occupations, we plan to make a secondary analysis to analyze the influence of occupations' domain (healthcare vs. non-healthcare) on social judgments.
In this case, four ANOVAs with occupation’s domain (healthcare vs. non-healthcare) and the eight occupations as within-subjects variables will be performed to analyze the influence of domain on the four sub-dimensions of social judgments. Participants’ political orientation will be used as covariate.

sample.value:
We need a total sample of 92 participants to detect a small effect size (f = .10) with an alpha of .05 and power of .80 for a mixed model ANOVA testing the interaction between two groups and four measurements (analysis conducted using G*Power, Faul et al., 2007)
Thus, we aim to recruit around 100 participants (50 in each between-subject condition).

analyses.value: Four ANOVAs with gender (men vs. women) as between-subject variable and the eight occupations as within-subject variable will be performed to analyze the influence of workers’ gender and occupations on the four sub-dimensions of social judgments. Participants’ gender and political orientation will be used as covariate.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who don't live currently in France.
No outliers criteria defined a priori.

dependent.value:
4 items of social judgments on four sub-dimensions (Brambilla & Leach, 2014; Fiske et al., 2007): competence (i.e., "effective"), agency (i.e., "self-confident"), sociability (i.e., "pleasant"), and morality (i.e., "honest"). 
Participants will be asked to what extent these adjectives could describe different workers on scales ranging from 0 (not at all) to 100 (totally).

conditions.value:
Two between-subjects conditions varying according to workers' gender (men vs. women).
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions.

hypothesis.value: The aim of this first study is to analyze the social judgments made towards different occupations in the time of COVID-19.

attributes.title: TEORIA DO COMPORTAMENTO PLANEJADO APLICADA À SEGURANÇA DO PACIENTE: SCOPING REVIEW
attributes.description: mapear a evidência disponível sobre o uso da Teoria do Comportamento Planejado – TPB (do inglês Theory Planned Behavior) na identificação dos comportamentos e seus determinantes psicossociais dos comportamentos relacionados à segurança do paciente adotados por trabalhadores de contexto hospitalar. Trata-se de Scoping Review realizada seguindo as etapas do Joanna Briggs Institute e as recomendações do Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews e Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews. Para tanto, acessaram-se as bases de dados: SCOPUS, PUBMED, LILACS, Web of Science, CINAHL e BDENF. Os critérios de inclusão foram: estudos originais, publicados nos idiomas inglês, português ou espanhol com diferentes delineamentos metodologias, sem limite de tempo, que respondessem à questão de pesquisa, isto é, envolvendo o cenário hospitalar e trabalhadores de saúde. Os resultados foram sumarizados por similaridade. Foram encontrados 30 estudos, a maior parte com desenhos transversais (70,0%), originários dos Estados Unidos (20,0%). Os comportamentos foram sumarizados em se grupos: adesão à protocolos de higiene de mãos (30,0%); notificação de incidentes com medicamentos (16,7%) estratégias/adesão a protocolos de medicação segura (13,3%); adesão à protocolos/rotinas para a segurança do paciente (13,3%);   notificação de incidentes de segurança (10,0%); adesão à protocolos de cirurgia segura (10,0%); comunicação segura (6,7%).A identificação dos determinantes dos comportamentos dos trabalhadores no cenário assistencial pode representar etapa fundamental para intervenções que visem maior adesão aos protocolos de segurança do paciente.

attributes.title: Global Generosity in Times of Crisis
attributes.description: How and why do people across countries and cultural groups display generosity behaviors when faced with an unprecedented health crisis such as COVID-19?

summary.value:
We intend to study global generosity behaviors and motivations across countries and cultural groups, especially in the context of the 2020 Corona crisis. We will use a mixed-methods approach, where we combine open-ended interviews, survey research and an archival study. In the survey we will ask both closed and open-ended questions to get to an inclusive understanding of the concept, behavior and motivations related to generosity across the globe, in particular in times of crisis. In the archival study, we will collect stories of generosity behavior as reported through television news, newspapers, and social media across the world. 

The question we aim to answer is:
How and why do people across countries and cultural groups display generosity behaviors, especially when faced with an unprecedented health crisis such as COVID-19?

q1.value: The Effect of Self-World Fit on Right-Wing Authoritarianism

q3.value: The psychology and sociology of authoritarianism has been a subject of intense interest since the Second World War. Prominent articles have suggested a relationship between so-called authoritarian predisposition, as measured by child-rearing attitudes, and measures of manifest authoritarianism. This relationship is though to be moderated by a construct called normative threat, or a threat to the cohesion, unity, or success of an in-group. The relationship between authoritarian predisposition and manifest authoritarianism remains key to the modern sociological paradigm of authoritarianism; the psychological mechanism by which normative threat activates authoritarianism, however, has not been explored. We test the efficacy of a construct we defined as self-world fit as moderators of the relationship between authoritarian disposition and manifest authoritarian attitude. Should we find that self-world fit moderate the relationship between child-rearing attitude and right wing authoritarianism, this may suggest that self-world fit captures some of the pathways by which normative threat activates authoritarianism.

q4.value:
It is hypothesized that:
1) (observational) The relationship between authoritarian predisposition, operationalized with a four-question child-rearing scale, and authoritarian attitude, operationalized using the Right-Wing Authoritarianism scales, will be moderated by self-world fit. Lower self-world fit will lead to a stronger (more positive) relationship between disposition and attitude. 
2) (experimental) If our manipulation successfully lowers self-world fit, we expect to observe a stronger correlation between disposition (as operationalized above) and attitudes (as operationalized above) in the conditions of low self-world fit.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Experiment: 
Between subjects design with 1 factor (self-world fit) and 2 conditions (high, low) 

We will attempt to manipulate self-world fit using a novel and subtle manipulation. We will ask personal questions which relate to socioeconomic class and social and behavioral engagements. All questions will be multiple choice. In the 'low self-world fit' condition, the ranges of each answer choice will lead the majority of people to fall on the 'undesirable' end of the distribution; in the 'high self-world fit' condition, the ranges of each answer choice will lead people to fall in the 'desirable' end of the distribution. For example: participants in both conditions will be asked, "How often do you engage in more than a half-hour of intensive exercise?". In the low self-world fit condition, the answer choices are as follows: a) 0-6 times a week. b) once a day. c) twice a day. d) three times a day. e) more than three times a day. In the high self-world fit condition, the answer choices are as follows: a) never. b) once every few months. c) about once a month. d) a few times a month. e) more than once a week.

After the manipulation, we will measure authoritarian attitude (RWA), authoritarian predisposition (child-rearing attitudes), self-world fit, political preferences, and general demographics. If the manipulation is successful, we expect the 'high' condition to have higher self-world fit, or both. If the manipulation is successful, we expect the relationship between authoritarian predisposition and authoritarian attitudes to be stronger in the low condition than the high condition.

Observational:
We will further observe the efficacy of self-world fit as a moderator of the relationship between child rearing attitudes and manifest authoritarian attitudes. This relationship will be tested using multiple regression. Additional tests may be run to assess self-world fit as a moderator of the child-rearing RWA relationship.

q9.value: The subjects will be randomly assigned into one of two equally-signed conditions using Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon MTurk. Participants will be compensated $0.2 for their involvement. Participants must be at least 18 years old, be located in the U.S., have HIT approval ratings higher than 95%, and have more than 5,000 HITS approved. The participants will not have participated  in our pilot or other pertinent studies.  If sufficient participants are not recruited within a few days, the pay may be raised, and the latter two (HIT-related) constraints may be lowered.

q13.value: We will recruit  450 participants (~225 per condition)

q14.value: Based on a pilot we ran, the effect size seems relatively small, and 450 participants is an adequate balance of a sample size and economic considerations.

q15.value: If we accidentally collect more data prior to any analysis, we will keep this data.

question.value: We manipulate the answer-choices to a set of questions participants are shown. In doing so, we are trying to subtly manipulate self-world fit.

Right-Wing Authoritarianism Scale: A six-item shortened scale from Bizumic and Duckitt (2018), called Very Short Authoritarianism scale.

Self-World Fit Scale: This is a scale the authors of this paper have created. This version of it is a six-question scale.

Child-Rearing Scale: A four-question scale similar to the scale used in the ANES.

Works Cited
Bizumic, B., Duckitt, J. (2018). Investigating Right Wing Authoritarianism With a Very Short Authoritarianism Scale. Journal of Social and Political Psychology, 6(1), 129–150.

We will be looking at Cronbach's alphas of all scales we use, to aid in assessing the efficacy of the scales. We will also look at the simple correlations between variables in our study to help understand the interaction of the constructs at play.

Observational Study:
Multiple regression to test self-world fit as moderators of the relationship between child-rearing and RWA. 
Binary split of  self-world fit to graph relationship between child-rearing and RWA with self-world fit at different percentiles (relationship between child-rearing and RWA for the 50% of subjects with lower self-world fit vs 50% with higher self-world fit). 
Fisher's R-to-Z transformation to test significance of binary split.
We may use plots to visualize some of this data.

Experiment:
Manipulation check: ANOVA to test effect of condition on self-world fit
First test of significance: Two-way ANOVA to test interaction between condition and child rearing attitudes in predicting authoritarian attitudes (RWA)
Second test of significance: Fisher's R-to-Z to test significance of difference in correlation between conditions.
We may use plots to visualize this data.

While we may run additional tests that are suggested by our findings, such tests would be post-hoc and exploratory and thus should not be considered part of this pre-registration.

q20.value:
RWA & Self-World Fit are measured as the sum of the responses to individual questions that compose them. 

The traditional child-rearing scale is a binary scale, where people select there view of whether one or another trait is more important for children to have. We aimed to make a more sensitive scale, so our measure of child-rearing attitudes is a six-point Likert scale; otherwise, the scale is identical to the child-rearing scales used elsewhere. We may collapse the six-point scale to a binary scale, should reviewers request that we adjust the data to reflect how it is commonly collected.

q21.value: We will use the standard p=.05 criteria for determining statistical significance. We will use a two-tailed test in our analyses.

q22.value: We will exclude data if 1) the subject fails our initial test of competence, which prevents the subject from participating in the study; or 2) the subject has universally, without discriminating between questions whatsoever selected the same answer choice (e.g., the top or bottom choice throughout). The initial tests of competence includes a captcha verification box, a prompt to select the most accurate statement, with the options being: "I am @ rabbit", "I am @ lion", and "I am @ human" in legible hand-writing, and a short blurb with a question that tests comprehension. These questions are intended to screen for bots and people who don't adequately speak English.

q23.value: Most of the data we request, the subjects are required to submit. We will keep all submissions (subject to the exclusion criteria) who respond to RWA, child-rearing attitudes, and self-world fit, regardless of whether political opinions and demographic information. We will not keep all participants who fail to respond to RWA, child-rearing attitudes, or self-world fit.

q24.value: After our main dependent variables and manipulation check, we ask a number of questions relating to political opinion (views about calls to 'lock up' political opponents and calling mainstream media 'fake news'; belief about whether the U.S. President should be constrained in their ability to make change, and belief in God). We also request demographic information, including party affiliation, ideology, education level, age, race, sex, zip code, employment status, and income. We will use this for exploratory analysis, correlating demographic information and political views with measures of authoritarianism (RWA), and self-world fit. We also intend to correlate a number of questions with self-world fit, primarily about income, status, and social alienation; the intent is to help conceptualize self-world fit.

q25.value: We expect a relatively small effect size, but believe that, should we find that self-world fit is a real moderator of the relationship between child-rearing and authoritarian attitudes, this is an interesting and important fact.
